==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|alt=和上,和闍,和社,鶻社,殟社,烏社}}

===Etymology===
“Senior monk who holds the precepts-granting ceremony; [[preceptor]]” > “high priest; head monk” > “Buddhist monks in general”. First attested in the 3<sup>rd</sup>–4<sup>th</sup> centuries, as {{zh-l|*和上}}.

Borrowed from {{der|zh|pra}} ''uvajjhāa'', ''uajjhāa'', ''ujjhāa'', ''ojjhāa'', ''ojhāa'', ''ujjhā'', ''ujjha'' (“teacher; religious teacher”), all ultimately derived from {{der|zh|sa|उपाध्याय||teacher; preceptor; spiritual adviser}} ({{zh-ref|Chu, 2002}}). The use of {{zh-l|*上}} or {{zh-l|*尚}} {{IPAchar|/d͡ʑɨɐŋ<sup>H</sup>/}} to render Prakrit ''jjhāa'' {{IPAchar|/d̚d͡ʑʱɑː.ɐ/}} was probably influenced by:
# The loss of the nasal ''–ŋ'' coda in the ancient northwestern dialect of Middle Chinese, and
# The use of {{zh-psm|nocap=1}} in transcription, with {{lang|zh|尚}} taken to mean “noble; virtuous; to revere” ([[idem]]).

Compare {{cog|pi|upajjhāya}}, {{m|pi|upajjhā}}, {{m|pi|upajjha||spiritual teacher or preceptor}}, {{cog|hi|ओझा||exorcist}}, {{cog|sd|واڍو}} / {{m|sd|वाढो|tr=vāḍho||carpenter}}, {{cog|as|ওজা|tr=ûza||one well-versed in any art; teacher; sorcerer}}, {{cog|bn|ওঝা||snake-charmer; exorcist}}, {{cog|or|ଓଝା|tr=ojhā||teacher; one who cures snake-bites; wizard; exorcist; title of blacksmiths and carpenters}}, {{cog|ml|വാധ്യായന്‍||teacher; family priest}}, {{cog|ta|வாத்தியார்||teacher; family priest; one who trains actors and dancers}}.

Alternative theories, such as those put forth by [[Tang]] Dynasty monks {{w|Yiqiejing yinyi (Xuanying)|Xuanying}} and {{w|zh:慧苑|Huiyuan}}, hypothesise that this was borrowed from [[Khotanese]] or language of the [[疏勒|Shule]] Kingdom, but these appear less likely.
